title: ISO :27001 Clauses
description: Securing your online account login credentials
longDescription: Most reported data breaches are caused by the use of weak, default, or stolen passwords. This section covers best practices for passwords, multi-factor authentication, and secure login habits, organized into specific security domains.

domains.title: Governance
domains.longDescription: Establishing a strong governance framework for authentication ensures that policies are consistently applied, roles are clearly defined, and the overall strategy aligns with business objectives.

domains.title: Asset Management
domains.longDescription: Properly managing authentication-related assets, such as password databases and hardware tokens, is crucial for maintaining security and accountability throughout their lifecycle.

domains.title: Information Protection
domains.longDescription: This domain focuses on the technical controls and processes required to protect sensitive authentication data, like password hashes and biometric information, from unauthorized access or disclosure.

domains.title: Human Resource Security
domains.longDescription: Integrating authentication management with HR processes ensures that access is granted, modified, and revoked in a timely manner as employees join, change roles, or leave the organization.

domains.title: Physical Security
domains.longDescription: This domain covers the measures needed to protect physical authentication factors, such as smart cards, hardware tokens, and the facilities where critical authentication systems are housed.

domains.title: System and Network Security
domains.longDescription: Ensuring the underlying systems and networks that process authentication requests are secure is fundamental to preventing credential theft and unauthorized access.

domains.title: Application Security
domains.longDescription: This domain focuses on implementing secure authentication mechanisms within applications, including session management, password policies, and protection against common attacks like credential stuffing.

domains.title: Secure Configuration
domains.longDescription: Properly configuring authentication services, such as directory services and single sign-on platforms, is critical to eliminate vulnerabilities and enforce security policies.

domains.title: Identity and Access Management
domains.longDescription: The core of authentication security. Use long, strong, and unique passwords, manage them in a secure password manager, enable 2-factor authentication, keep on top of breaches, and take care while logging into your accounts.

items.security: Use a Strong Password
items.details: If your password is too short, or contains dictionary words, places, or names, then it can be easily cracked through brute force or guessed by someone. The easiest way to make a strong password is by making it long (12+ characters) — consider using a 'passphrase' made up of many words. Alternatively, use a password generator to create a long, strong random password. Have a play with [Security.org's How Secure Is My Password?](https://security.org/how-secure-is-my-password/), to get an idea of how quickly common passwords can be cracked. Read more about creating strong passwords: [securityinabox.org](https://securityinabox.org/en/passwords/passwords-and-2fa/).

items.security: Don't Reuse Passwords
items.details: If someone were to reuse a password and one site they had an account with suffered a leak, then a criminal could easily gain unauthorized access to their other accounts. This is usually done through large-scale automated login requests, and it is called Credential Stuffing. Unfortunately, this is all too common, but it's simple to protect against — use a different password for each of your online accounts.

items.security: Use a Secure Password Manager
items.details: For most people, it is going to be near-impossible to remember hundreds of strong and unique passwords. A password manager is an application that generates, stores, and auto-fills your login credentials for you. All your passwords will be encrypted against 1 master password (which you must remember, and it should be very strong). Most password managers have browser extensions and mobile apps, so whatever device you are on, your passwords can be auto-filled. A good all-rounder is [Bitwarden](https://awesome-privacy.xyz/essentials/password-managers/bitwarden), or see [Recommended Password Managers](https://awesome-privacy.xyz/essentials/password-managers).

items.security: Avoid Sharing Passwords
items.details: While there may be times that you need to share access to an account with another person, you should generally avoid doing this because it makes it easier for the account to become compromised. If you absolutely do need to share a password — for example, when working on a team with a shared account — this should be done via features built into a password manager.

items.security: Enable 2-Factor Authentication
items.details: 2FA is where you must provide both something you know (a password) and something you have (such as a code on your phone) to log in. This means that if anyone has your password (e.g., through phishing, malware, or a data breach), they will not be able to log into your account. It's easy to get started, download [an authenticator app](https://github.com/Lissy93/awesome-privacy#2-factor-authentication) onto your phone, and then go to your account security settings and follow the steps to enable 2FA. Next time you log in on a new device, you will be prompted for the code that is displayed in the app on your phone (it works without internet, and the code usually changes every 30 seconds).

items.security: Keep Backup Codes Safe
items.details: When you enable multi-factor authentication, you will usually be given several codes that you can use if your 2FA method is lost, broken, or unavailable. Keep these codes somewhere safe to prevent loss or unauthorized access. You should store these on paper or in a safe place on disk (e.g., in offline storage or an encrypted file/drive). Don't store these in your password manager as 2FA sources and passwords should be kept separately.

items.security: Sign Up for Breach Alerts
items.details: After a website suffers a significant data breach, the leaked data often ends up on the internet. Several websites collect these leaked records and allow you to search your email address to check if you are in any of their lists. [Firefox Monitor](https://monitor.firefox.com), [Have I Been Pwned](https://haveibeenpwned.com), and [DeHashed](https://dehashed.com) allow you to sign up for monitoring, where they will notify you if your email address appears in any new data sets. It is useful to know as soon as possible when this happens so that you can change your passwords for the affected accounts. [Have i been pwned](https://awesome-privacy.xyz/security-tools/online-tools/have-i-been-pwned) also has domain-wide notification, where you can receive alerts if any email addresses under your entire domain appear (useful if you use aliases for [anonymous forwarding](https://github.com/Lissy93/awesome-privacy#anonymous-mail-forwarding)).

items.security: Shield your Password/PIN
items.details: When typing your password in public places, ensure you are not in direct line of sight of a CCTV camera and that no one can see over your shoulder. Cover your password or pin code while you type, and do not reveal any plain text passwords on your screen.

items.security: Update Critical Passwords Periodically
items.details: Database leaks and breaches are common, and, likely, several of your passwords are already somewhere online. Occasionally updating passwords of security-critical accounts can help mitigate this. But providing that all your passwords are long, strong, and unique, there is no need to do this too often — annually should be sufficient. Enforcing mandatory password changes within organisations is [no longer recommended](https://duo.com/decipher/microsoft-will-no-longer-recommend-forcing-periodic-password-changes), as it encourages colleagues to select weaker passwords.

items.security: Don’t Save your Password in Browsers
items.details: Most modern browsers offer to save your credentials when you log into a site. Don’t allow this, as they are not always encrypted and could allow someone to gain access to your accounts. Instead, use a dedicated password manager to store (and auto-fill) your passwords.

items.security: Avoid Logging In on Someone Else’s Device
items.details: Avoid logging in on other people's computers since you can't be sure their system is clean. Be especially cautious of public machines, as malware and tracking arr more common here. Using someone else's device is especially dangerous with critical accounts like online banking. When using someone else's machine, ensure that you're in a private/incognito session (Use Ctrl+Shift+N/ Cmd+Shift+N). This will request the browser to not save your credentials, cookies, and browsing history.

items.security: Avoid Password Hints
items.details: Some sites allow you to set password hints. Often, it is very easy to guess answers. In cases where password hints are mandatory, use random answers and record them in your password manager (`Name of the first school: 6D-02-8B-!a-E8-8F-81`).

items.security: Never Answer Online Security Questions Truthfully
items.details: If a site asks security questions (such as place of birth, mother's maiden name, or first car, etc.), don't provide real answers. It is a trivial task for hackers to find out this information online or through social engineering. Instead, create a fictitious answer, and store it inside your password manager. Using real words is better than random characters, as [explained here](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=29244870).

items.security: Don’t Use a 4-digit PIN
items.details: Don’t use a short PIN to access your smartphone or computer. Instead, use a text password or a much longer PIN. Numeric passphrases are easy to crack (A 4-digit pin has 10,000 combinations, compared to 7.4 million for a 4-character alpha-numeric code).

items.security: Avoid Using SMS for 2FA
items.details: When enabling multi-factor authentication, opt for app-based codes or a hardware token if supported. SMS is susceptible to several common threats, such as [SIM-swapping](https://www.maketecheasier.com/sim-card-hijacking) and [interception](https://secure-voice.com/ss7_attacks). There's also no guarantee of how securely your phone number will be stored or what else it will be used for. From a practical point of view, SMS will only work when you have a signal and can be slow. If a website or service requires the usage of an SMS number for recovery, consider purchasing a second pre-paid phone number only used for account recovery for these instances.

items.security: Avoid Using your PM to Generate OTPs
items.details: Many password managers are also able to generate 2FA codes. It is best not to use your primary password manager as your 2FA authenticator as well, since it would become a single point of failure if compromised. Instead, use a dedicated [authenticator app](https://github.com/Lissy93/awesome-privacy#2-factor-authentication) on your phone or laptop.

items.security: Avoid Face Unlock
items.details: Most phones and laptops offer a facial recognition authentication feature, using the camera to compare a snapshot of your face with a stored hash. It may be very convenient, but there are numerous ways to [fool it](https://www.forbes.com/sites/jvchamary/2017/09/18/security-apple-face-id-iphone-x/) and gain access to the device through digital photos and reconstructions from CCTV footage. Unlike your password, there are likely photos of your face on the internet and videos recorded by surveillance cameras.

items.security: Watch Out for Keyloggers
items.details: A hardware [keylogger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware_keylogger) is a physical device planted between your keyboard and the USB port, which intercepts all keystrokes and sometimes relays data to a remote server. It gives a hacker access to everything typed, including passwords. The best way to stay protected is just by checking your USB connection after your PC has been unattended. It is also possible for keyloggers to be planted inside the keyboard housing, so look for any signs that the case has been tampered with, and consider bringing your own keyboard to work. Data typed on a virtual keyboard, pasted from the clipboard, or auto-filled by a password manager can not be intercepted by a hardware keylogger.

items.security: Consider a Hardware Token
items.details: A U2F/FIDO2 security key is a USB (or NFC) device that you insert while logging in to an online service to verify your identity instead of entering a OTP from your authenticator. [SoloKey](https://solokeys.com) and [NitroKey](https://www.nitrokey.com) are examples of such keys. They bring with them several security benefits. Since the browser communicates directly with the device, it cannot be fooled as to which host is requesting authentication because the TLS certificate is checked. [This post](https://security.stackexchange.com/a/71704) is a good explanation of the security of using FIDO U2F tokens. Of course, it is important to store the physical key somewhere safe or keep it on your person. Some online accounts allow for several methods of 2FA to be enabled.

items.security: Consider Offline Password Manager
items.details: For increased security, an encrypted offline password manager will give you full control over your data. [KeePass](https://awesome-privacy.xyz/essentials/password-managers/keepass) is a popular choice, with lots of [plugins](https://keepass.info/plugins.html) and community forks with additional compatibility and functionality. Popular clients include: [KeePassXC](https://keepassxc.org) (desktop), [KeePassDX](https://www.keepassdx.com) (Android) and [StrongBox](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/strongbox-password-safe/id897283731) (iOS). The drawback being that it may be slightly less convenient for some, and it will be up to you to back it up and store it securely.

items.security: Consider Unique Usernames
items.details: Having different passwords for each account is a good first step, but if you also use a unique username, email, or phone number to log in, then it will be significantly harder for anyone trying to gain unauthorised access. The easiest method for multiple emails, is using auto-generated aliases for anonymous mail forwarding. This is where [anything]@yourdomain.com will arrive in your inbox, allowing you to use a different email for each account (see [Mail Alias Providers](https://github.com/Lissy93/awesome-privacy#mail-forwarding)). Usernames are easier since you can use your password manager to generate, store, and auto-fill these. Virtual phone numbers can be generated through your VOIP provider.

domains.title: Threat and Vulnerability Management
domains.longDescription: Proactively identifying, assessing, and mitigating vulnerabilities in authentication systems is essential to defend against evolving threats.

domains.title: Continuity
domains.longDescription: Planning for disruptions to authentication services ensures that users can maintain access to critical systems during an incident.

domains.title: Supplier Relationships Security
domains.longDescription: When relying on third-party providers for authentication services, it is crucial to manage the associated security risks through due diligence and contractual agreements.

domains.title: Legal and Compliance
domains.longDescription: Ensuring that authentication practices comply with relevant legal, statutory, and regulatory requirements is a critical aspect of information security.

domains.title: Information Security Event Management
domains.longDescription: Having a formal process for managing authentication-related security incidents is key to minimizing their impact and learning from them to prevent recurrence.

domains.title: Information Security Assurance
domains.longDescription: Regularly assessing and auditing authentication controls provides assurance that they are implemented correctly and operating effectively.

domains.title: Cryptography
domains.longDescription: Cryptography is the cornerstone of secure authentication, used to protect passwords in transit and at rest, and to ensure the integrity of authentication messages.

title: A.5 – Organizational Controls
description: Define the organization’s governance, policies, and processes to manage information security systematically.
longDescription: Organizational controls are the foundation of an Information Security Management System (ISMS). They define how an organization establishes its governance, policies, responsibilities, and processes to manage information security in a structured, consistent, and proactive manner.

title: People Controls (A.6)
description: Ensure that employees and contractors understand and fulfill their information security responsibilities.
longDescription: People controls focus on managing the human factors of information security. They ensure that all individuals involved with the organization are properly screened, trained, and made aware of their security obligations, both during and after employment.

domains.title: 6.1 Screening
domains.description: This control ensures that individuals hired or engaged by the organization are trustworthy and suitable for their roles—especially those with access to sensitive information. It helps reduce the risk of insider threats, fraud, or misuse of information assets.
domains.longDescription:
Background verification 
checks on all candidates to 
become personnel shall be 
carried out prior to joining 
the organization and on an 
ongoing basis taking into 
consideration applicable 
laws, regulations and ethics 
and be proportional to the 
business requirements, the

information to be accessed

items.security: Is there a screening process for onboarding full-time, part-time and temporary staff?
items.details:
Meaning:
The assessor is asking whether your organization has a formal, documented process for screening all types of personnel — not just permanent employees, but also:

Part-time staff

Temporary workers

Contractors

Interns or consultants

What to show/evidence:

HR policy or recruitment policy describing the screening procedure.

Workflow or checklist for background checks.

Documentation showing consistent application across all personnel types.

items.security: Are background verification checks carried out on all new candidates for employment?
items.details:
This asks whether every new hire goes through a background verification process before employment is finalized.
It verifies that no one bypasses the process — even in urgent hiring situations.

What to show/evidence:

Records of completed checks (or a confirmation from the background screening vendor).

HR hiring checklist showing this step.

Policy mandating background verification before onboarding.

items.security: Does the background verification process consider checking professional experience, academic qualifications, independent identity verification, criminal records verification and credit review?
items.details:
This question tests the scope and depth of the verification process.
A comprehensive background check typically includes:

Professional experience: Employment history validation.

Academic qualifications: Degree/diploma verification.

Identity verification: Confirming the candidate’s legal identity.

Criminal record check: Ensuring no relevant offenses that would pose risk.

Credit review: (especially for financial or high-trust roles).

What to show/evidence:

Vendor reports or HR internal forms listing these checks.

Policy specifying which checks apply to which job roles.

Example anonymized verification results.

items.security: Are the checks compliant with relevant laws, regulations and ethics?
items.details:
The organization must conduct checks legally and ethically. This includes:

Following local labor laws and data protection/privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR).

Obtaining candidate consent before performing checks.

Limiting the scope of checks to what’s necessary for the role (“proportional to the business requirements”).

What to show/evidence:

Documentation of compliance with local laws.

Consent forms from candidates.

Privacy policy explaining how candidate data is used and stored.

Legal or compliance team guidance.

domains.title: 6.2 Terms and  conditions of  employment
domains.description: The employment  contractual agreements  shall state the personnel’s  and the organization’s  responsibilities for  information security.

items.security: Is there a formal terms and conditions of employment documented and communicated to all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff before onboarding?
items.details: The assessor wants to confirm that your organization has a formal, documented employment contract or agreement that outlines the terms and conditions for every category of employee — full-time, part-time, temporary, and contractual — and that it is communicated and signed before joining.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

HR or onboarding policy requiring contracts before start date

Signed employment contracts (sample copies)

Offer letter templates referencing employment terms

Onboarding checklist or HRIS record showing acknowledgment

items.security: Do the terms and conditions of employment include the organization’s Information Security Policy and relevant topic-specific policies?
items.details: The assessor checks if the employment contract or onboarding process introduces and binds personnel to comply with the organization’s information security policy, including related policies such as Acceptable Use, Data Protection, or Confidentiality.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Employment contract referencing Information Security Policy

Employee handbook or induction materials with policy links

Signed acknowledgment of policy receipt or awareness training completion

items.security: Do the terms and conditions of employment include legal responsibilities and rights such as copyright laws or data protection legislations?
items.details: The assessor wants to ensure the organization’s employment documentation includes legal clauses covering intellectual property rights, copyright protection, and compliance with applicable data protection laws (like GDPR, IT Act, etc.).
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Employment contract sections on confidentiality and intellectual property

Signed NDA (Non-Disclosure Agreement)

Legal review or HR policy referencing data protection obligations

items.security: Do the terms and conditions of employment include responsibilities for the handling of information received from interested parties?
items.details: The assessor checks whether employees are contractually obligated to protect and correctly handle information from customers, suppliers, and partners (interested parties).
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Contract clauses on confidentiality of third-party data

NDA or code of conduct referencing external information protection

Supplier/customer data handling procedures in HR documentation

items.security: Do the terms and conditions of employment include actions to be taken if personnel disregard the organization’s security requirements?
items.details: The assessor checks whether the organization clearly defines disciplinary actions or sanctions for employees who violate information security or company policies.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Employment contract or HR manual section on disciplinary procedures

Security policy mentioning consequences for violations

HR records showing examples of policy enforcement (if applicable)

domains.title: 6.3 Information  security  awareness,  education and  training
domains.description: Personnel of the  organization and relevant  interested parties shall  receive appropriate  information security  awareness, education and  training and regular  updates of the  organization's information  security policy, topic specific policies and  procedures, as relevant for  their job function.

items.security: Do all employees, contractors, and third-party users undergo regular information security awareness training appropriate to their role and function within the organization?
items.details: The assessor is checking whether the organization has implemented a formal, ongoing information security awareness and training program for all personnel — including full-time staff, contractors, and external parties — that matches their job responsibilities and risk exposure.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Annual or periodic security awareness training calendar.

Attendance logs or completion records for all employees and third parties.

Role-based training materials (e.g., admin, developer, HR-specific modules).

Evidence of refresher training (e.g., phishing simulation reports, awareness campaigns).

items.security: Does the information security awareness program cover the organization’s information security policy and topic-specific policies, as well as applicable standards, laws, regulations, contracts, and agreements?
items.details: The assessor wants to ensure that the awareness program educates employees about the organization’s policies and legal obligations, ensuring personnel understand both internal rules and external compliance requirements that apply to their work.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Training materials or slide decks covering InfoSec policies and legal compliance.

Policy acknowledgment forms signed by staff.

Training syllabus referencing laws, standards, or contracts.

Record of updates when new regulations or policies are introduced.

items.security: Does the information security awareness program include training on personal accountability and individual responsibilities for protecting organizational and third-party information?
items.details: The assessor is checking if personnel are trained to understand that information security is everyone’s responsibility — including how their own actions or inactions can lead to security incidents.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Awareness content on “individual responsibility” or “secure behavior.”

Examples of role-specific security practices (e.g., password hygiene, data handling).

Signed declarations or acknowledgment forms from employees.

Internal communications reinforcing security culture (emails, posters, intranet messages).

items.security: Does the organization have a formal process to assess the effectiveness of the information security awareness program (e.g., through quizzes, phishing simulations, or post-training evaluations)?
items.details: The assessor wants to verify that the organization not only delivers training but also measures its effectiveness — ensuring employees understand and apply what they’ve learned.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Post-training quiz or assessment results.

Metrics from phishing awareness campaigns or scenario-based testing.

Feedback forms or surveys on training sessions.

Awareness KPI reports shared with management.

domains.title: 6.4 Disciplinary  process
domains.description: A disciplinary process shall  be formalized and  communicated to take  actions against personnel  and other relevant  interested parties who have  committed an information  security policy violation.

items.security: Is there a formal disciplinary process that allows the organization to take action against employees who commit an information security breach?
items.details:
The assessor is checking whether the organization has a documented disciplinary policy that defines how violations of information security policies are handled.

The process should clearly explain:

What constitutes a security breach

Types of disciplinary actions

Escalation levels

Roles and responsibilities for investigation and action
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Documented disciplinary policy or HR manual

Section of employment contract referencing disciplinary actions

Records of past disciplinary actions (if applicable)

items.security: Is the formal disciplinary process approved by top management?
items.details: The assessor wants to confirm that the disciplinary process has official endorsement from senior leadership, which shows commitment to enforcing information security requirements.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Policy approval page with signatures of top management

Change approval logs

Management review minutes confirming approval

items.security: Is the formal disciplinary process communicated to all employees?
items.details:
The assessor checks whether employees are made aware of the disciplinary measures and the consequences of violating security policies.

Communication should occur through:

Onboarding

Email broadcasts

Policy acknowledgment

Employee handbook

Awareness training
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Training attendance records

Signed policy acknowledgments

Employee handbook containing the disciplinary process

Intranet or HR portal communication

items.security: Does the formal disciplinary process consider relevant factors before taking action?
items.details:
The assessor is verifying whether the disciplinary process is fair, consistent, and proportional, taking into consideration multiple elements of the security breach.

The process should evaluate:

Nature of the breach (who, what, when, how)

Gravity of the breach and its consequences

Intentional vs. unintentional behaviour

First-time or repeated offence

Whether the violator was properly trained and informed

Impact on organization or interested parties

Level of negligence or malicious intent
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Policy sections outlining assessment factors

Case records showing applied considerations

Investigation templates or checklists

domains.title: 6.5 Responsibilities After Termination or Change of Employment
domains.description: Information security  responsibilities and duties  that remain valid after  termination or change of  employment shall be  defined, enforced and  communicated to relevant  personnel and other  interested parties.

items.security: Does the employee termination process define the information security responsibilities and duties that remain valid after termination or change of job role for all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff?
items.details:
The assessor is verifying whether the organization has a formal and documented offboarding process that ensures personnel understand what information security duties continue even after they leave the organization or change roles.

These ongoing responsibilities include:

Continuing confidentiality obligations

Non-disclosure of sensitive or proprietary information

Returning all organizational assets (laptop, ID card, access tokens, documents)

Removal of access rights immediately after termination

Protecting customer/supplier information even after exit
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Offboarding/exit procedure in HR or ISMS documentation

Exit clearance checklist including InfoSec responsibilities

Records proving timely access revocation

Termination workflow documents from HRMS system

items.security: Are the responsibilities and duties that remain valid after termination of employment or contract included in the individual’s terms and conditions of employment, contract, or agreement?
items.details:
The assessor wants to confirm that employees and contractors are contractually bound to maintain confidentiality and protect organizational and third-party information even after they leave the organization.

These obligations should be formally stated in:

Employment contracts

Consultant/contractor agreements

Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs)

IP protection and confidentiality clauses

Terms and conditions of employment or assignment
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

Employment contract section on post-termination obligations

NDA signed at the time of joining

Contractor agreements with confidentiality terms

Exit acknowledgment or certification form confirming awareness

domains.title: 6.6 Confidentiality or Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs)
domains.description: Confidentiality or non disclosure agreements  reflecting the organization’s  needs for the protection of  information should be  identified, documented,  regularly reviewed and  signed by personnel and  other relevant interested  parties.

items.security: Are all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff required to sign a confidentiality or non-disclosure agreement (NDA) prior to gaining access to the organization’s confidential information and associated assets?
items.details:
The assessor is verifying whether the organization ensures that no employee or contractor is given access to sensitive, confidential, or proprietary information before signing a formal NDA or confidentiality clause.

This includes:

New hires (full-time, part-time, interns, temporary workers)

Contractors and third-party personnel

Consultants with system or data access

The NDA must be signed before access to systems, networks, or data is provided.
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

NDA templates used by HR or Legal

Signed NDA forms for a sample of employees

Contract agreements containing confidentiality clauses

Onboarding checklist proving NDA is completed before access provisioning

items.security: Do the confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements include the required elements, such as:  Definition of the information to be protected  Validity period of the agreement  Ownership of information, trade secrets, and intellectual property  Terms for returning or destroying information upon termination?
items.details:
Meaning:
The assessor is checking whether the NDA is comprehensive and legally enforceable, and whether it clearly outlines each party’s obligations regarding confidential information.

A complete NDA should include:

Description of protected information (e.g., business data, customer info, IP, credentials)

Duration/validity (e.g., obligations continue after employment ends)

Ownership clauses for information, trade secrets, and intellectual property

Return or destruction obligations for documents, equipment, or digital assets at exit

Consequences for breach of confidentiality

Restrictions on unauthorized sharing or disclosure
items.observation:
What to show / Evidence:

NDA document with all required clauses

Legal review or version history proving regular updates

Signed copies for employees, contractors, and vendors

Exit checklist showing return/destruction of information at termination

domains.title: 6.7 Remote  working
domains.description: Security measures shall be  implemented when  personnel are working  remotely to protect  information accessed,  processed or stored outside  the organization’s premises.

items.security: Is there a formal, documented policy that defines the information security requirements for allowing personnel to work remotely and access the organization’s information?
items.details:
The assessor is verifying whether the organization has an officially approved and published Remote Working Policy that clearly states the conditions, controls, and security measures required for accessing corporate information outside the organization’s premises.

A formal Remote Working Policy should:

Define who is permitted to work remotely

List security requirements such as VPN, MFA, encryption, secure Wi-Fi

Specify acceptable use rules for devices and remote access

Include physical security expectations (private workspace, lockable storage, no sharing of devices)

Define handling, storage, printing, and disposal rules for sensitive information

Establish responsibilities of employees when working from home or public places

Be reviewed regularly and approved by top management
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Official Remote Working Policy document (PDF or online copy)

Approval records from top management

Policy communication records to employees (emails, LMS, HR onboarding documents)

Employee acknowledgment logs or digital signatures
X`
Version history showing policy updates and reviews

items.security: Is the remote working policy formally approved by top management before being implemented and communicated?
items.details:
The assessor wants to confirm that the Remote Working Policy has received official authorization from the organization’s top management, ensuring:

The policy aligns with business goals

Management accepts responsibility for enforcing it

Adequate resources are allocated to support its requirements

The policy carries organizational authority and is not an informal or draft document

Top management approval demonstrates that:

The policy is recognized as mandatory

It supports ISO 27001 governance requirements

Employees must comply with its rules and controls

Approval typically includes signatures, email confirmations, or governance meeting minutes.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Approved policy document with management signatures/date

Board or management meeting minutes showing approval

Email or memo from leadership confirming policy adoption

Document control records showing version approval

Policy management system logs showing “Approved” status

items.security: Is the remote working policy formally communicated to all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff who work remotely?
items.details:
The assessor is checking whether the organization ensures that every individual who works remotely—regardless of their employment type—receives, understands, and acknowledges the Remote Working Policy.

This ensures:

All remote workers are aware of security requirements

No personnel are operating without proper guidance

Policy expectations, responsibilities, and restrictions are clearly understood

Compliance is maintained uniformly across the organization

Communication should be done before remote access is granted.

Effective communication may include:

Email distribution

HR onboarding workflows

Learning Management System (LMS) modules

Internal portals or document management systems

Mandatory acknowledgments or digital signatures
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Email communication logs or announcements

LMS training completion reports

HR onboarding checklists including policy acknowledgment

Signed acknowledgment forms (HR, DMS, or digital signatures)

Evidence that part-time, temporary, and contractual staff also received the policy

items.security: Does the remote working policy include physical security requirements to ensure protection of organizational information at remote work locations?
items.details:
The assessor wants to verify whether the Remote Working Policy clearly defines physical security expectations for employees working outside the organization’s premises.

This ensures that sensitive information remains protected even when personnel work from:

Home offices

Client locations

Shared coworking spaces

Public environments (hotels, cafés, airports)

The policy should address:

Maintaining a secure, private workspace

Preventing unauthorized individuals from viewing or accessing information

Using lockable storage (cabinets, drawers) for documents

Ensuring devices are not left unattended

Protecting screens from shoulder surfing in public places

Secure handling of physical documents (no printing in insecure areas)

Safe transport of notebooks, files, and media between locations

These controls prevent physical theft, accidental exposure, or unauthorized access.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Remote Working Policy document with a dedicated “Physical Security” section

Guidelines for secure workspaces (home office setup requirements)

Clear desk and clear screen rules

Employee onboarding material highlighting physical security expectations

Awareness training slides or LMS modules covering physical security

Evidence of reminders or periodic communications sent to remote staff

items.security: Does the remote working policy  consider of the remote working site  such as lockable filing cabinets, secure  transportation between locations and  rules for remote access, clear desk,  printing and disposal of information.
items.details:
The assessor is checking whether the organization’s Remote Working Policy clearly defines how information should be protected at the remote work location—both physically and operationally.

A strong policy should include guidance on:

1. Secure Storage:

Use of lockable filing cabinets or drawers

No sensitive documents left in open or shared spaces

Secure storage for laptops, removable media, and printed materials

2. Secure Transportation:

Safe movement of files and devices between office and home

Use of sealed folders/bags

Avoiding unattended equipment during travel

3. Remote Access Requirements:

Use of VPN, MFA, encryption, and approved devices only

No use of personal, public, or shared systems for corporate data

4. Clear Desk & Clear Screen:

Screens locked when away

Sensitive items cleared from the desk when not in use

Protection from shoulder surfing or observers

5. Printing Controls:

Printing allowed only when necessary

Use of home printers secured from shared access

No printing in public or coworking spaces

6. Disposal of Information:

Shredding or secure destruction of physical documents

Following approved disposal procedures for sensitive material

No disposal via home or public trash bins

This ensures that sensitive data is not exposed through poor remote handling practices.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Sections in the Remote Working Policy covering storage, transport, access, clear desk, and disposal

Secure workspace guidelines or setup checklists

Employee awareness training content addressing information handling at home

Evidence of periodic reminders or internal communications

Documentation that employees acknowledged these requirements

Photos or self-attestation forms (if implemented) showing secure home workspace setup

items.security: Does the remote working policy include communications security requirements, ensuring that all data transmitted from remote locations is protected from interception, tampering, or unauthorized access?
items.details:
The assessor is checking whether the Remote Working Policy defines clear rules and security controls for how employees should communicate and access organizational information while working remotely.

A robust remote communications security section should include:

1. Secure Connection Requirements

Mandatory VPN usage

Encrypted communication channels (HTTPS, TLS-encrypted email, encrypted messaging tools)

Prohibition of insecure or open Wi-Fi networks

2. Authentication Controls

Mandatory MFA for remote access

Strong password policies

Device identity verification (trusted devices only)

3. Network Security Controls

Use of organization-approved firewalls, endpoint protection, and anti-malware tools

Blocking of unauthorized or risky communication applications

Restrictions on peer-to-peer tools, public proxies, or anonymous networks

4. Email & Messaging Security

Rules on sending sensitive data (encryption, approval, classification)

Prohibition of personal email or consumer messaging apps for work content

5. Secure Use of Collaboration Tools

Guidelines for video conferencing (waiting rooms, no public meeting links)

Restrictions on file sharing platforms unless approved (e.g., SharePoint, OneDrive)

These requirements ensure that information remains confidential, authenticated, and protected in transit, even outside the corporate network.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Remote Working Policy with a dedicated Communications Security section

VPN, MFA, and endpoint protection enforcement records

Network usage guidelines or acceptable use policies

Email security guidelines and classification rules

Screenshots or logs showing secure communication tools in use

Employee training material related to communication security

items.security: Does the remote working policy address the risk of unauthorized access to information or resources when employees work in public locations (e.g., cafés, airports, coworking spaces)?
items.details:
The assessor is verifying whether the organization has defined how employees should protect sensitive information when working in public or semi-public environments where strangers may be able to observe or access data.

A strong policy should include:

1. Screen Protection:

Mandatory use of screen privacy filters

Prohibition of working with sensitive information in open public areas

Requirement to lock the screen when stepping away

2. Physical Awareness:

Avoiding shoulder surfing or visibility to nearby individuals

Keeping devices within reach at all times

Not leaving laptops or documents unattended

3. Public Network Risks:

Avoiding public Wi-Fi or mandatory use of VPN when unavoidable

No direct access to corporate apps without secure channels

Restrictions on using unknown or untrusted networks

4. Audio/Conversation Security:

Avoid discussing confidential topics in public

Use of headsets instead of speakerphones

Awareness of surroundings during calls or meetings

5. Handling of Documents and Devices:

No printing or reading sensitive documents in public

Securely carrying laptops and files using protective bags

No disposal of documents in public areas

These controls minimize the risk of accidental exposure or malicious access in public zones.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Remote Working Policy section addressing public place usage

Clear guidelines in Acceptable Use or BYOD policies

Awareness training modules covering risks of public working

Communication reminders sent to employees

Employee acknowledgment or compliance tracking

items.security: Does the remote working policy require the use of security measures such as firewalls, anti-malware tools, endpoint protection, and other defensive controls on devices used for remote access?
items.details:
The assessor is checking whether the Remote Working Policy ensures that all devices used for remote work—whether company-issued or approved personal devices—have appropriate baseline security protections.

A comprehensive policy should require:

1. Firewalls:

Enabled host-based firewalls on all work devices

Blocking unauthorized inbound/outbound connections

Restricting access to untrusted networks

2. Anti-Malware & Endpoint Protection:

Mandatory installation of organization-approved anti-malware tools

Real-time protection and regular scanning

Prohibition of disabling security controls without authorization

3. Security Updates & Patching:

Up-to-date OS and application patches

Automatic updates enabled

Regular compliance checks by IT or security teams

4. Device Hardening:

Full disk encryption

USB and external media restrictions

Application whitelisting or zero-trust endpoint controls

5. Network Security:

Enforced secure configurations for home routers (e.g., WPA3, strong passwords)

Prohibiting outdated or insecure network equipment

These controls reduce risks of malware infections, data breaches, or unauthorized access when accessing corporate resources remotely.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Remote Working Policy document highlighting firewall and anti-malware requirements

Endpoint protection deployment reports

Device compliance logs (MDM, EDR, or AV dashboards)

Screenshots or logs showing firewall and EDR tools installed

Patch management reports for remote endpoints

Awareness training materials for secure device usage

domains.title: 6.8 Information  security event  reporting
domains.description: The organization shall  provide a mechanism for  personnel to report  observed or suspected  information security events  through appropriate  channels in a timely  manner.

items.security: Are all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff made aware of their responsibility to report observed or suspected information security events?
items.details:
The assessor is checking whether personnel understand that reporting security events is mandatory, not optional.
This includes events like:

Suspicious emails or phishing attempts

Unauthorized system access

Lost/stolen devices

Malware infections

Accidental data exposure

Policy violations

The organization must ensure every individual knows they are personally accountable for reporting these events promptly.

Awareness may come through:

Security training

Employee handbooks

Policy documents

Onboarding programs

Internal communications (email, portal, posters)
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

ISMS policies referencing reporting responsibilities

Security awareness training content

Training attendance or completion reports

HR onboarding documents emphasizing reporting duties

Communication logs reminding employees of reporting responsibility

items.security: Are all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff made aware of the procedure for reporting information security events?
items.details:
The assessor is verifying if employees know how to report an incident—not just that they should report it.

A documented reporting procedure should include:

Steps to follow when an event is detected

Initial containment actions (if applicable)

Whom to contact (team/role)

What information to include in the report

Timelines (e.g., report immediately or within X hours)

Escalation flow in case the primary contact is unavailable

Procedure should be available and accessible to everyone.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Documented incident reporting procedure

Incident response plan with reporting workflow

Training content explaining event reporting steps

Onboarding checklist including reporting procedure

Internal portal/screenshots where procedure is published

items.security: Are all full-time, part-time, and temporary staff made aware of the communication contact details and communication medium for reporting security events?
items.details:
The assessor is ensuring that personnel know exactly where and how to report incidents, such as:

Communication channels may include:

Dedicated incident reporting email (e.g., security@company.com
)

Hotline or emergency phone number

Ticketing system (e.g., ServiceNow, Jira)

Security operations portal or form

Reporting via line manager (if part of the process)

Employees must know:

Who receives these reports

Which channels are primary vs. secondary

When to use each method (e.g., urgent phone call vs. normal ticket)

This ensures quick, consistent, and reliable reporting.
items.observation:
What to Show / Evidence

Policy or guidelines listing reporting contacts

Posters, emails, or intranet pages with reporting details

Onboarding materials showing communication channels

Awareness campaigns or reminders

Incident response plan with contact directory

title: Physical Controls (A.7)
description: Protect physical environments and assets from unauthorized access, damage, or interference.
longDescription: Physical controls ensure that facilities, systems, and equipment are protected from physical threats such as theft, fire, or environmental damage. They establish secure perimeters, control access to buildings and rooms, and safeguard infrastructure to maintain confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information.

title: Technological Controls (A.8)
description: Implement technical safeguards to protect systems, networks, and data from unauthorized access, misuse, or disruption.
longDescription: Technological controls apply technical measures to secure information systems, networks, and data against threats. These include access management, malware protection, encryption, system configuration, and continuous monitoring to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information.
